awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  The integration of smart wearables in the telehealth management workflow
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to design a care-centered digital health platform for remote symptom monitoring of Parkinson’s Disease patients. Parkinson’s is a progressive neurological disorder affecting various movement and mobility, sleep quality, emotional and behavioral health, and other factors, with symptoms manifesting individually. Approximately 10 million people around the world currently live with Parkinson’s Disease. The total economic burden of Parkinson’s is roughly $51.9 Billion in the U.S. alone. Patient-provider communication is a significant challenge.  This project proposes a digital health platform offering a patient-friendly mechanism for reporting symptoms and experiences in daily-life settings to the care team.    

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will design and pilot an interoperable digital health framework with an overarching objective to address the challenges of remote symptom monitoring. Neurologists have insufficient confidence in the patient-generated self-reports (paper-based logs) as they can be prone to biases and over-/under-reporting. This research will explore integrating commonly used smart wearables (such as smartwatches and smart finger rings) into a digital health platform to offer symptom monitoring services. A key technical challenge is to make the integration of wearables interoperable within the standards of electronic health records (EHR). Another focus is to identify appropriate data reporting and presentation for clinical oversight and decision-making.  The project will pilot the digital health platform on patients with Parkinson’s and clinicians to measure feasibility and performance and to evaluate its potential to scale.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In the NSF Phase I project (December 2021 to May 2023), our mission was to improve patient access and experiences for people with Parkinson's Disease (PD) and their caregivers through the PD-Aware platform. With a unique blend of wearable technology integration, personalized user feedback, and a virtual care-first strategy, we developed PD-Aware, to enhance patient and clinician experiences using an advanced digital health platform. This innovative app, compliant with HIPAA (Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act), connects a user-friendly interface with a secure cloud-based data management system, encapsulating our response to a long-standing healthcare gap.

 

Objective 1: Patient-Centric Digital Health Framework Design

Our first objective was to integrate daily used wearables (such as smartwatches) with the PD-Aware application. The app design uses the Flutter development environment for cross-platform compatibility. Our team dedicated significant effort towards creating a comprehensive digital framework, PD-Aware, which combines wearable data with personalized patient feedback based on insights from clinical consultants and breaking down patient-reported outcome questionnaires. Secure data ingestion, analysis, and integration were facilitated through Google Cloud and Healthcare API, ensuring optimal performance and reliability. The combination of a user-friendly, action-centric interface that adheres to health information technology specifications and standards, PD-Aware bridges the gap in tracking patient-reported outcomes, notably quality of life metrics.

 

Objective 2: Clinician-Centric Dashboard Enhancement

Working hand-in-hand with neurologists and movement disorder specialists, we co-designed a clinician dashboard that enhances data visualization and provides detailed reports to guide clinical decision-making. This collaborative design process resulted in a tool designed specifically for the needs and workflows of healthcare professionals.

 

Objective 3: Feasibility Pilot Testing and Data Analysis

After receiving full institutional review board?s ethical approval, we conducted a feasibility study that assembled a diverse group of PD patients and their caregivers. Their valuable feedback reflected high usability ratings and provided invaluable insights for further enhancements. A pilot study involving 31 people with PD and 14 caregivers demonstrated usability and robustness, yielding an average rating of 4.75/5. Furthermore, 94.5% of participants continued use of the app beyond the study period. One participant described PD-Aware as, ?a pleasant, brief connection to a caring system.? Another remarked that it is ?a really easy tool to use to collect data on a number of fields that impact the daily life of PD?.  

Data collection and analysis yielded valuable insights. Over the course of the study, we gathered 2,827 days' worth of participant data, which proved instrumental in providing context and tracking the progression of PD symptoms. Additionally, the data density distribution analysis helped detect outliers or patterns within the data, contributing to the continuous refinement of the platform. ​​Participants in the feasibility study received comprehensive results as a form of the final study report. Their feedback through exit interviews became a critical foundation for the ongoing improvement and implementation of the PD-Aware application. Additional metrics were discussed, paving the way for future enhancements to the app.

 

Future Directions and Impact

PD-Aware transcends the conventional confines of remote patient monitoring, serving as a key facilitator for enhancing patient access and promoting patient-centric experiences through its 'virtual care first' strategy. This revolutionary approach overhauls traditional healthcare workflows, leading to comprehensive transformation in the provision of care.

The platform enriches the experience of clinicians and healthcare staff by providing an integrated interface to effectively track and analyze patient-reported outcomes. As PD-Aware continues to evolve, it is set to become a crucial asset for delivering personalized, efficient, and high-impact care to those living with PD.

As we navigate through Phase II, we are channeling insights garnered from our feasibility study to further refine PD-Aware's predictive capabilities. By boosting its precision in tracking and predicting disease progression, we aim to equip patients and healthcare providers with actionable insights that enhance disease management and ultimately, patient health outcomes.

In terms of broader implications, PD-Aware is on the cusp of reshaping telehealth paradigms for PD management. By elevating patient engagement and empowering clinicians to tailor individualized care, our platform holds the promise of improving patient experiences and accessibility for those battling PD.

Guided by our commitment to a virtual care-first strategy, we foresee PD-Aware inspiring a shift towards proactive, preventive, and personalized healthcare. In this vein, we aim to enhance not only clinician and staff experiences but also to democratize access to specialized care, thus bridging geographic disparities in healthcare provision.

Looking ahead, we envision PD-Aware as an indispensable tool in the arsenal for PD management. The prospect of healthcare providers readily recommending PD-Aware underscores our dedication to instigating a paradigm shift in the way specialized care is approached, delivered, and perceived.
